ask_evacuation: Follow official flood warnings from German authorities such as BBK (Federal Office of Civil Protection) or your local municipality.
Move immediately to higher ground if water levels are rising. Never wait until roads become blocked.
Do NOT drive through flooded streets. Even 30 cm of moving water can sweep away vehicles.
Take emergency essentials: ID documents, medication, phone chargers, drinking water, and warm clothing.
If evacuating in Germany, shelters are often set up in sports halls (Turnhallen), schools, or community centers.
ask_first_aid: If someone is injured during flooding: move them away from water hazards first.
For severe bleeding: apply firm direct pressure with a clean cloth. Call emergency services immediately.
If hypothermia is suspected (cold, shaking, confusion): wrap the person in dry blankets and seek urgent medical help.

ask_shelter: If your home is unsafe due to flooding, go to a designated evacuation shelter (Notunterkunft) announced by local authorities.
In Germany, temporary shelters are commonly located in city halls, sports halls, and Red Cross support centers.
Bring essential items, but avoid carrying heavy luggage.
If you have children, elderly people, or pets, inform shelter staff immediately so proper care can be arranged.
